awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SAI: Developing Effective and Culturally Appropriate Alaskan Housing: Performance metrics for future builds based on an interdisciplinary ethnography of past projects
awd_abstract_narration:
Strengthening American Infrastructure (SAI) is an NSF Program seeking to stimulate human-centered fundamental and potentially transformative research that strengthens America’s infrastructure. Effective infrastructure provides a strong foundation for socioeconomic vitality and broad quality of life improvement. Strong, reliable, and effective infrastructure spurs private-sector innovation, grows the economy, creates jobs, makes public-sector service provision more efficient, strengthens communities, promotes equal opportunity, protects the natural environment, enhances national security, and fuels American leadership. To achieve these goals requires expertise from across the science and engineering disciplines. SAI focuses on how knowledge of human reasoning and decision making, governance, and social and cultural processes enables the building and maintenance of effective infrastructure that improves lives and society and builds on advances in technology and engineering.

This SAI EAGER award supports an interdisciplinary team of anthropologists, educators, builders, and engineers investigating the successes and failures of past housing projects in remote Alaskan communities. They are working with local research assistants to combine building diagnostics, local insights, socio-economic data, and culturally specific housing design. The team is working towards the creation of a repository of designs and findings that is available on an open-source platform. The data produced from this study will inform and strengthen future Alaskan infrastructure investments, and the research methods will lay the groundwork for similar research investigations in dozens of communities. The project broadens participation in engineering through collaborative research activities, makerspace activities, and community engagement.

The housing security crisis in rural Alaska, exacerbated by climate change and highlighted by the recent pandemic, places immense burdens on resource-strapped communities. While large-scale investments to address these problems may be on the horizon, there is a clear need for cutting-edge research and socially rich data on rural Alaskan housing to guide future projects and avoid mistakes of the past. This research project tackles this knowledge deficit with an experimental collaboration of experts and community members from inside and outside Alaska who are developing integrated techniques and ethnographically informed understandings of the infrastructural impacts that recent cold-climate demonstration homes have on the lived experiences of Alaskans. The research team is investigating the successes and failures of cold-climate demonstration homes in two distinct eco-regions (inland Brooks Range and coastal Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta). They are integrating ethnographic data with building diagnostics using human factors and engineering methods to assess the performance of construction practices. Data will be shared and co-analyzed during online participatory design workshops involving experts and community stakeholders who are invested in rural Alaska housing security issues. The community approach will reveal experiential knowledge of housing affordances, burdens, and expenses, and will result in a collection of post-design data related to housing security in rural Alaska. Data is also being used to develop performance metrics and guidance for future building projects in formats that meet the needs of communities or agencies. Taken together, these materials are providing content for an eventual design repository. Finally, the integrative methodology developed in this project lays the foundation for longer term research examining additional post-design sites. This project’s focus on the effects of the built environment on communities and the generalizability of the methods from the case studies will be replicable not just in other regions of Alaska, but in other appropriate regions of the U.S.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This study integrated construction engineering and anthropology to safely and responsibly collect data on housing issues in remote communities in Alaska during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The focus included socio-cultural, technical, economic, environmental, and logistical aspects of designing, building, maintaining, and living in homes. To share knowledge, we piloted content and representations for a cold climate housing design repository that will be co-created and designed for accessible public access to:

1.     enfranchise Tribal and community members and maximize the benefits of working with a team of design anthropologists, engineers, economists, builders, architects, and home occupants;

2.     support Alaska housing investment initiatives and community planning efforts.

Three questions guided this project:

1) How can post-design investigations of the socio-cultural effects and technical performance of cold climate housing contribute to human-centric approaches for strengthening remote Alaskan infrastructures?

To document the impacts of home building projects in remote Alaska Native communities, our team collaborated across physical distance with embedded community research assistants to interview residents. The homes were built by the Fairbanks-based Cold Climate Housing Research Center (CCHRC), and we also interviewed these architects and builders. During this 2-year NSF SAI grant, field work included 52 interviews and over 15 workshops. The team analyzed the data to (1) evaluate the performance of designs and construction practices; (2) co-analyze findings in online participatory design workshops; and (3) co-produce three case studies from remote villages in Alaska.

2) What are best practices for carrying out remote interdisciplinary research on arctic infrastructure in the face of major obstacles, such as times of crisis and across distances (both cultural and geographic)?

The project PIs trained Community Research Assistants (CRAs) in three remote communities. The CRAs collaborated in data collection and were compensated with NSF funding. This model of working with residents enabled the research to be conducted in practical ways during times when the researchers could not travel to the sites due to pandemic restrictions and proved to be a culturally responsive mode of working with community members. CRAs helped create interview questions, recruit participants, facilitate interviews, and analyze results.

3) How can participatory processes be used to co-create a design repository of publicly accessible resources and also be used to broaden participation in engineering?

The research team explored alternative ways of co-creating and sharing findings, including an open-source graphical publication that depicts and describes the range of modular housing designs; an annotated literature review combining news media, policy documents and academic sources; and participatory images in the form of games and digital and 3D-printed objects. These resources can be used by professionals working in Alaska for the first time and in educational settings to teach about the complexities of building homes in the North. This work is also the basis for an engineering M.S. thesis at Virginia Tech by Emily Brown on using visuals to communicate housing designs.

Findings were also shared in academic venues (American Society of Engineering Education, Society for Applied Anthropology, Alaska Anthropological Association) and in Alaskan housing events and meetings (Alaska Housing Innovation Summit, Alaska Housing Finance Corporation, Association of Alaska Housing Authorities), city governments, and undergraduate and graduate courses in engineering, anthropology, and design disciplines.

Conclusions:

This research into diverse perspectives on planning, building, financing, and living in homes constructed in remote Alaskan villages shows that houses not designed for the various and extreme environmental conditions will deteriorate rapidly and will fail to address needs and values of Alaska Native communities. A primary consideration for research in remote areas of Alaska and with Alaska Natives is to include community members as both research participants and participant researchers. We adapted and implemented a Community Research Assistant model to work with embedded local liaisons. Research co-created and conducted across distance is time-intensive and requires persistence to identify and involve people and organizations that are relevant to the problem space. Participatory processes that carefully include this range of contributors can result in generating questions that matter to stakeholders and people whose voices are often not included, knowledge based on both experience and expertise, and planning that reveals the range of variables that impact decision-making.

Brown, E. 2023. Considering Indigenous Cultural History and the Use of Visual Communication to Improve Design Repository Documents for the Cold Climate Housing Research Center in Fairbanks, Alaska. Master’s Thesis, Virginia Tech.
